chip showed the (0.333, 0.373) color coordinate and high color-rendering index (
provide a platform for development of new eﬃcient phosphors in solid-state lighting ﬁeld.
Recently, many researchers have focused their attention on
rare-earth-doped phosphor materials for solid-state lighting,
especially in white light-emitting diodes (w-LEDs). Commer-
cialized w-LEDs are made up of a blue-emitting LED chip and
However, they exhibit a low color-rendering index (CRI)
because they generate weak red emission.
problem, optimal phosphors should be newly developed.
Therefore, new classes of phosphors based on metal silicates,
metal sulﬁdes, metal oxy-nitrides, and metal nitrides have been

commercialized YAG:Ce phosphor by Varadaraju et al.
Recently, the crystal structure and PL properties of Eu
have been elucidated and discussed by Kulshreshtha
, i. e., the hexagonal crystal system
nm, respectively. Based on the structures of the host materials
(M = Ca, Sr, and Ba), it is presumed that the
luminescent properties of these phosphor materials may be
closely related to the chemical environment around the Eu
activator ion. It is well known that alkaline-earth silicon
oxynitride phosphors with the RE-ion activator (RE = Ce
, etc.) have been intensively studied in recent years
because they are potential candidate materials for improving
the low luminous eﬃciency and low CRI for w-LEDs.
